RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Bolsista de doutorado direto pela Capes (Coordenao de Aperfeioamento de Pessoal de Nvel Superior), possui graduao em Licenciatura plena em Matemtica pela Universidade de So Paulo (2010). Atualmente aluno do Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais no curso de Geofsica Espacial.

OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES: MONITORIA: Monitor da disciplina de VETORES E GEOMETRIA ANALTICA pelo Centro Universitrio Unifeo, com a orientao da Dra. MARIA ELISA ESTEVES LOPES GALVO. (1sem/2006)

DOUTORADO.NOME-AGENCIA: Coordenao de Aperfeioamento de Pessoal de Nvel Superior

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Estudo dos intervalos de tempo entre descargas de retorno de raios negativos
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Observao de relmpagos utilizando sensores de campo eltrico, juntamente com cmeras de alta resoluo temporal para estudo da variao de tempo entre as descargas de retorno de raios, analisando a relao com a durao de correntes contnuas e com os picos de corrente de cada descarga.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Estudo dos intervalos de tempo entre descargas de retorno de raios negativos

ATUACAO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO: South Dakota School of Mines and Technology

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: High-speed Video and Electrical Study of Upward Lightning Triggered by Towers
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This research seeks to address how upward lightning is triggered from tall structures. Existing literature and previous observations suggest that nearby flashes can create conditions favorable for upward leader initiation from tall objects. The objective is to quantify and understand these conditions and determine a triggering flash component responsible for upward leader initiation. A combination of electromagnetic and optical sensors will record upward lightning flashes from multiple towers in Rapid City, South Dakota. Electromagnetic sensors will include electric field meters, fast and slow field change sensors, and two interferometers. Operation of these sensors will be coordinated with high-speed video, tandard definition video, and digital still image cameras. Observations made with these assets will be analyzed along with National Lightning Detection Network (NLDN) and meteorological data (i.e., radar, satellite, thermodynamic sounding and meteorological surface parameters) to determine types of flashes and their properties that affect or are critical for the initiation of upward leaders from tall objects, storm type, region and stage of development during which upward lightning occurs, and the conditions for triggering upward leaders on multiple tall objects during the same flash.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: This research seeks to address how upward lightning is triggered from tall structures. Existing literature and previous observations suggest that nearby flashes can create conditions favorable for upward leader initiation from tall objects. The objective is to quantify and understand these conditions and determine a triggering flash component responsible for upward leader initiation. A combination of electromagnetic and optical sensors will record upward lightning flashes from multiple towers in Rapid City, South Dakota. Electromagnetic sensors will include electric field meters, fast and slow field change sensors, and two interferometers. Operation of these sensors will be coordinated with high-speed video, tandard definition video, and digital still image cameras. Observations made with these assets will be analyzed along with National Lightning Detection Network (NLDN) and meteorological data (i.e., radar, satellite, thermodynamic sounding and meteorological surface parameters) to determine types of flashes and their properties that affect or are critical for the initiation of upward leaders from tall objects, storm type, region and stage of development during which upward lightning occurs, and the conditions for triggering upward leaders on multiple tall objects during the same flash.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: High-speed Video and Electrical Study of Upward Lightning Triggered by Towers

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: High-speed video and electromagnetic analysis of two natural bipolar cloud-to-ground lightning flashes

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: High-speed video records of two bipolar cloud-to-ground flashes were analyzed in detail. They both began with a single positive return stroke that was followed by more than one subsequent weak negative stroke. Due to the elevated cloud base height of its parent thunderstorm, the preparatory processes of each subsequent negative stroke were documented optically below cloud base. In the first event (Case 1) it was observed that all four subsequent negative strokes were initiated by recoil leaders that retraced one horizontal channel segment previously ionized by the positive leader. Those recoil leaders connected to the original vertical channel segment and propagated toward ground, producing four subsequent strokes that had the same ground contact point as the original positive discharge. The second event (Case 2), in contrast, presented 15 subsequent strokes that were initiated by recoil leaders that did not reach the original channel of the positive stroke. They diverged vertically toward ground, making contact approximately 11 km away from the original positive strike point. These results constitute the first optical evidence that both single- and multiple-channel bipolar flashes occur as a consequence of recoil leader activity in the branches of the initial positive return stroke. For both events their total channel length increased continuously at a rate of the order of 104 m s−1, comparable to speeds reported for typical positive leaders.
